name: Lynx R1
description:
Initially featuring an integrated eye tracking mechanism and intended for businesses, the Lynx R-1 was later redesigned to be sold to consumers. This resulted in the removal of its eye tracking functionality, as well as the launch of a Kickstarter campaign to crowdfund the device.

Backers of the Kickstarter campaign will have the opportunity to obtain a version of the device featuring a transparent front faceplate, revealing the internals of the device.
headstrap: Plastic halo strap with flip-up visor

name: VRgineers XTAL 3
description:
The XTAL 3 features advanced features enabled by its integrated eye tracking, including gaze analysis and dynamic foveated rendering.

The headset was designed in cooperation with a group international Air Force pilots, and is designed to offer a superlative field of view and resolution compared to other devices. It is firmly targeted at the business market, and is made primarily for use in simulation activities.

The XTAL 3 can be purchased without a license, but it can also be purchased with a business or military license, costing $800 more and $1600 more respectively.
specData-handTracking: Optional Ultraleap hand tracking, not included on base model

name: VRgineers XTAL 3 Mixed Reality
description:
The XTAL 3 Mixed Reality features two high-fidelity mixed reality cameras with interchangable lenses. Each lens provides a different field of view, with more restricted fields of view offering higher visual fidelity and PPD, and larger fields of view offering a lower PPD for the user.

The XTAL 3 Mixed Reality can be purchased without a license, but it can also be purchased with a business or military license, costing $800 more and $1600 more respectively.
specData-handTracking: Optional Ultraleap hand tracking, not included on base model

name: VRgineers VRHero 5K Plus
description: The VRHero 5K Plus is a modified VRHero 5K that makes use of OLED displays rather than the LCD displays found on the original headset.

name: Lenovo Mirage VR S3
description: The Lenovo Mirage VR S3 is a standalone headset by Lenovo, scheduled for release in Q3 2020. It has a very high resolution for a standalone headset, currently only less than that of the DPVR P1 Pro 4K.

The Lenovo ThinkReality A3 can only be used with a very small range of Lenovo & Motorola products. These include:

- Lenovo ThinkPad P1 Gen 1-4

- Lenovo ThinkPad P15 Gen 1-2

- Lenovo ThinkPad P17 Gen 1-2

- Lenovo ThinkPad P53

- Lenovo ThinkPad P73

- Motorola Moto G100

name: Lenovo Legion VR700
description:
The Lenovo VR700 is marketed as a part of the company's Legion line of gaming devices.

The Lenovo VR700 will be the first headset to be released by the company after its board of directors was joined by Cher Wang Hsiueh Hong, the co-founder and chairwoman of HTC, known in the VR industry for its Vive brand of headsets.

The Lenovo VR700 will also be the first 6 DoF VR headset contributed to by Lenovo since the release of the Oculus Rift S, which was produced in a partnership between Oculus (now Meta) and Lenovo. The Lenovo VR700 also shares its retractable halo headstrap design with the headstrap of the Oculus Rift S.
controllerInputMethods: Face buttons, joystick, index trigger, middle finger trigger

name: Lenovo Glasses T1
description:
The Lenovo Glasses T1 is a wearable display marketed by the company as a portable solution for content consumption. The device takes a video signal over USB-C from a source laptop, tablet, or smartphone and displays it for the wearer.

The Lenovo Glasses T1 require an external adapter to be used with Lightning Connector-equipped devices such as iPhones.

name: Lenovo ThinkReality VRX
description:
The Lenovo ThinkReality VRX is Lenovo's first VR headset under their ThinkReality brand, previously known for augmented reality devices. It features a battery-counterbalanced headstrap and pancake optics to provide an effective weight distribution to the wearer.

The ThinkReality VRX also features dual color passthrough cameras to facilitate the use of mixed reality content on the headset, as well as an active cooling system that "channels heat from the display away from the wearer's face".

name: Xiaomi Mijia
description:
Xiaomi Mijia is a pair of standalone smart glasses designed to be used primarily for video recording, featuring a 50MP main front camera and an 8MP periscope camera with 5x optical zoom and 15x "hybrid zoom".

The Xiaomi Mijia can be connected to a smartphone via a companion app to allow for photos and videos to be exported from the headset. It also has a camera backtracking feature that allows the wearer to start a video capture up to 10 seconds after the intended start of recording.

name: Pico G2 4K Enterprise
description:
The Pico G2 4K Enterprise is equipped with various features optimised for business uses. This includes a "kiosk mode", that allows the device to be dedicated to a single VR application, and a removable PU leather facial interface that can easily be swapped and cleaned.

The Pico G2 4K Enterprise is sold with a 3 DoF controller, but it is also designed to allow hands-free control, with the user looking in specific locations while wearing the device to manipulate its interface.
cpu: Octa-core Kryo 280 (4 x 2.45 GHz, 4 x 1.9 GHz)

name: Pico Neo 3 Link
description:
Announced at Laval Virtual 2022, the Pico Neo 3 Link is available for purchase in European territories, with pre-orders for the opening on April 15th in many areas. The device will be sold in various locations including Germany, France, Spain, the Netherlands, Italy, and the UK.

The primary difference between the Pico Neo 3 Link and the original Pico Neo 3 is the ability to be used natively with a PC. The Neo 3 Link is capable of DisplayPort video connections via USB-C, and is shipped alongside a cable to allow the headset to be used with PC-powered VR content out of the box.
cpu: Octa-core Kryo 585 (1 x 2.84 GHz, 3 x 2.42 GHz, 4 x 1.8 GHz)

name: Pico 4
description:
Pico 4 is an upcoming Android-based standalone headset, developed by Pico Interactive as the successor to the Pico Neo 3. The name, which was leaked via FCC filings from the company, is a departure from the "Neo" name used for previous headsets from the same line.

The Pico 4 will be the first Pico headset to make use of pancake optics, which greatly reduces the form factor of the headset.
cpu: Octa-core Kryo 585 (1 x 2.84 GHz, 3 x 2.42 GHz, 4 x 1.8 GHz)

name: Pico 4 Pro
description:
Pico 4 Pro is an upcoming Android-based standalone headset, developed by Pico Interactive as the successor to the Pico Neo 3 Pro. The name, which was leaked via FCC filings from the company, is a departure from the "Neo" name used for previous headsets from the same line.

The Pico 4 Pro features some extra features over the Pico 4, including eye and face tracking cameras, and fully automatic hardware IPD adjustment.
cpu: Octa-core Kryo 585 (1 x 2.84 GHz, 3 x 2.42 GHz, 4 x 1.8 GHz)

name: Pico 4 Enterprise
description:
Pico 4 Enterprise is an Android-based standalone headset, developed by Pico Interactive as the successor to the Pico Neo 3 Pro, and features some extra features over the Pico 4, including eye and face tracking cameras, and fully automatic hardware IPD adjustment.

The Pico 4 Enterprise is a variant of the Pico 4 Pro, intended for release in western markets, and to be sold exclusively to business customers.
cpu: Octa-core Kryo 585 (1 x 2.84 GHz, 3 x 2.42 GHz, 4 x 1.8 GHz)

name: Pico G3
description:
The Pico G3 is the first 3 DoF standalone VR headset to incorporate a Qualcomm Snapdragon XR2 chipset, making it significantly more powerful than previous 3 DoF devices.

The Pico G3 is aimed at business customers, and is complete with a software suite to allow the headset to be used in business applications, including a business store, and remote control of multiple G3 units by a single host.
cpu: Octa-core Kryo 585 (1 x 2.84 GHz, 3 x 2.42 GHz, 4 x 1.8 GHz)

name: Pico 4 Ultra
description:
Pico 4 Ultra features a pair of integrated 32MP passthrough cameras, allowing for high fidelity mixed reality experiences. Additionally, this allows for the capture of spatial videos, up to a resolution of 2048x1536 at 60 fps and 50 Mbps.

Pico 4 Ultra features an improved Snapdragon XR2 Gen 2 processor, compared to the original Pico 4's XR2 Gen 1 chipset, providing a major performance uplift vs the base Pico 4.

Pico 4 Ultra features Pico's first pair of 6 DoF controllers that exclude a tracking ring, improving their form factor and reducing their height.
cpu: Octa-core Kryo (1 x 3.19 GHz, 4 x 2.8 GHz, 3 x 2.0 GHz)

name: Pico 4 Ultra Enterprise
description:
Pico 4 Ultra Enterprise is a business-focused version of Pico 4 Ultra.

It features enterprise-only features including a kiosk mode, remote device management, and play space sharing for multiple headsets.

Pico 4 Ultra features a pair of integrated 32MP passthrough cameras, allowing for high fidelity mixed reality experiences. Additionally, this allows for the capture of spatial videos, up to a resolution of 2048x1536 at 60 fps and 50 Mbps.

description:
Asus AirVision M1 features a companion app that allows for use as a virtual display with a source PC, including support for multiple virtual screens.

AirVision M1 is marketed as natively compatible with the ROG Ally, allowing for the device to be used as a virtual display for the console when connected.

name: XRSpace Manova
description:
Headset users will be able to access XRSpace Manova, a social VR platform by the same name.
 
 The headset can be used alongside the XRSpace Tracker, a wearable motion sensor designed to be wrapped around the user's wrist or ankle in order to enhance the tracking capabilities of the headset.

name: Acer OJO 500
description: The headset was initially planned to launch in November 2018, but was delayed until October 2019. The headset features a fully removable display, allowing for the device to be easily cleaned, as well as removable and customisable face plates. The OJO 500 features the same display found in their first VR release, the Acer AH101.

name: Pimax Reality 12K QLED
description:
The Pimax Reality 12K QLED is the first standalone headset released by the company.  It can be used natively as a PC-powered or standalone device. It also features a magnetic swappable face cushion, and a hot-swappable battery, which is located in the back of the headstrap.

The Pimax Reality 12K QLED is the first Pimax headset to feature automatic hardware IPD adjustment, enabled by its eye-tracking capabilities. It also features a dual-fan active cooling system.

name: Pimax Crystal QLED
description:
The Pimax Crystal QLED uses a glass aspherical lens design to improve light transmittance vs plastic lenses. It is also designed to maximise angular pixel density (PPD), with a signifianctly lower horizontal field of view than other Pimax devices, allowing for a significantly higher angular pixel density.

The Pimax Crystal QLED also features interchangeable lenses, with the option of alternative lenses that provide an increased FoV at the cost of angular pixel density.

The Pimax Crystal QLED also features interchangeable faceplates that allow for additional features including SteamVR 2.0 tracking and mixed reality color passthrough.

name: Pimax Portal View
description:
Pimax Portal View consists of a main unit and a pair of controllers which can be used as a traditional handheld games console, but can also be mounted into VR housings that allow for the device to be used as a standalone virtual reality headset.

While being used as a conventional handheld, the device can be used with the controllers mounted to the device, or with the controllers held freely in each hand.

While used in virtual reality mode, the main unit's integrated cameras are used to track the position of both itself and the controllers, which each mount into a VR controller housing to provide tracking markers, an ergonomic grip profile, and triggers for the user's middle and index fingers.

Pimax Portal QLED View consists of a main unit and a pair of controllers which can be used as a traditional handheld games console, but can also be mounted into VR housings that allow for the device to be used as a standalone virtual reality headset.

While being used as a conventional handheld, the device can be used with the controllers mounted to the device, or with the controllers held freely in each hand.

While used in virtual reality mode, the main unit's integrated cameras are used to track the position of both itself and the controllers, which each mount into a VR controller housing to provide tracking markers, an ergonomic grip profile, and triggers for the user's middle and index fingers.

The Pimax Portal QLED View features a QLED display with local dimming zones to provide improved contrast ratios over the Pimax Portal View.

name: Pimax Crystal Light
description:
Pimax Crystal Light is a modified version of Pimax Crystal, designed specifically to be used only as a PCVR headset. It features the same display and optical stack as Pimax Crystal, as well as the same pair of inside-out tracked controllers, but all features that enable standalone functionality have been removed. This means that the headset has no wireless capability, no integrated XR-2 chipset, and no integrated battery pack.

As a result of the removed standalone capability, Pimax Crystal light is significantly lighter than the original Pimax Crystal. The main body of Pimax Crystal light is advertised as 250 grams lighter than that of the original Crystal, while the headstrap is advertised as 60 grams lighter (due to the removal of the battery counterweight).

Pimax Crystal light is significantly cheaper than the original Pimax Crystal, partially due to the removal of standalone capability, but also due to other cost reduction measures including the removal of the headset's integrated eye tracking, automatic hardware IPD adjustment, and interchangeable optical stack.
controllerFingerTracking: Partial finger and thumb tracking via capacitive sensors
specData-handTracking: 120 Hz Ultraleap hand tracking sold separately

name: Pimax Crystal Super
description:
Pimax Crystal super features an interchangeable optical system, including both lenses and displays. This allows for the lenses in the headset to be replaced to modify the PPD, and also allows for the displays in the headset to be modified to allow the headset to be switched between QLED and Micro-OLED panels. Note that the lenses and displays are swappable as a single module, with the Micro-LED panels having narrower FoV lenses than the QLED panels.

Unlike the original Pimax Crystal, Pimax Crystal Super features no standalone capability, resulting in the headset having a reduced weight at the expense of having to be tethered to a PC.

Pimax Crystal Super also features higher resolution displays than the original Crystal, with 3840x3840 per-eye displays vs 2880x2880 per-eye for the original Crystal headset.
controllerFingerTracking: Partial finger and thumb tracking via capacitive sensors

name: Pimax Dream Air
description:
Pimax Dream Air is a lightweight  PC-powered VR headset making use of the same optical and display stack as the Pimax Crystal's pancake uOLED module. However, the headset uses a significantly weight-reduced chassis and smaller form factor to provide a highly ergonomic lightweight wearer experience.

Pimax Dream Air features native inside-out camera-based tracking and a pair of included tracked controllers, but is also advertised as lighthouse compatible, allowing use with SteamVR tracking.

Pimax Dream Air is Pimax's lightest VR headset release at the time of its announcement.
controllerFingerTracking: Partial finger and thumb tracking via capacitive sensors

description: The Huawei VR Glass 6DoF is the lightest positionally tracked VR headset to be released as of 2021. It weighs 188 g, making it a single gram lighter than the HTC Vive Flow. The headset shares many of its features and specifications with the original Huawei VR Glass, with the positional tracking being enabled by a tracking module attached to the top of the device. The Huawei VR Glass 6DoF also features a pair of 6 DoF controllers. This, alongside its ability to be connected to a PC via USB-C, allows the device to be used for PC-powered VR content, including SteamVR games.

description:
Huawei Vision Glass was announced on November 12 at the 2022 World Conference on VR Industry in Nanchang, China. The device is available to the Chinese consumer market and advertised as offering a large virtual screen to the wearer in a manner similar to products like the Nreal Air.

Huawei Vision Glass offers integrated blue light protection, and features adjustable diopter which removes the need for glasses to be worn under the headset.

The DPVR P1 Ultra 4K can be purchased alongside a NOLO 6 DoF tracking kit to provide positional tracking capability. The headset is also being sold to business customers with optional modules that can be included to provide extra tracking capabilities:

name: DPVR E4
description:
The DPVR E4 features a halo headstrap with a flip-up visor design, allowing the wearer to quickly switch between using the headset and seeing their physical surroundings. It also features a customisable LED light strip on the front of the device that allows wearers to choose a custom color.

The DPVR E4 was officially announced in late November during VRDays 2022 in Rotterdam. However, the device has been mentioned and teased multiple times in the months prior.

description:
The DPVR E4C is a variant of the DPVR E4, with its inside-out tracking capabilities and included controllers removed. The headset also features a reduced price when compared to the original E4, retailing for $398 vs $549 for the E4.

The DPVR E4C is primarily intended for the B2B market, being sold as a headset for use in seated simulators and other similar applications.

name: PlayStation VR
description:
PlayStation VR is the first VR headset to be released by Sony, and the first VR headset to be powered by a video game console. The headset was released as a peripheral for the PlayStation 4, and uses a pair of updated PlayStation Move controllers (originally used for the PS3) as its input mechanism.
 
 As of 2020, Playstation VR was the best-selling VR headset released up to that date, with over 5 million units sold.
controllerInputMethods: Face buttons, shoulder button, index trigger

name: PlayStation VR2
description:
The PlayStation VR2 is a 4K per-eye resolution VR headset, designed to be used alongside the PlayStation 5. The headset can be connected to the console via a USB Type-C connection. 

PlayStation VR2 is the first Sony VR headset to make use of eye tracking. It also features a motor built-in to the headset itself that can be used to provide a level of tactile feedback and amplify user immersion.

PlayStation VR2 is also advertised as having a HDR-capable display.

name: Sony PUD-J5A
description:
The Sony PUD-J5A was the first VR headset released for use with a PlayStation console. It was sold exclusively in Japan, and could be connected to a PlayStation 2 to play a small selection of compatible titles.

Six games were developed specifically to be used with the headset, making use of its head tracking capabilities:

- Energy Airforce
- Energy Airforce: Airstrike!
- Air Force Delta: Blue Wing Knights
- Sidewinder V
- Simple 2000 Vol.33: The Jet Coaster
- The Keihin Kyuukou: Train Simulator Real

The Sony SRH-S1 is a business-focused XR device, aimed for use in mixed reality applications.

The Sony SRH-S1 is designed in partnership with Siemens, and can be used with Siemens' NX immersive designer software so aid in product engineering applications.

The name, "SRH-S1" was officially revealed during AWE 2024.

name: HTC Vive Flow
description:
The HTC Vive Flow is an upcoming VR headset being designed by HTC. Codenamed "Hue", the product is designed as a casual VR viewer, intended for use as a media consumption device, with the ability to play some lighter casual games.

The headset is being shipped without controllers, but does feature a 6 DoF tracking system. In comparison to the now-defunct Oculus Go, the Vive Flow will be a more capable "casual" VR device due to its positional tracking capability.

The headset features an active cooling system, as well as frame similar to that found on many types of smart glasses. It also features an adjustable diopter, allowing near and far-sighted users to wear the device without glasses.

The HTC Vive Flow is designed to be used with a paired smartphone as a controller.

The HTC Vive Flow must be used with an external battery bank. The headset has an internal power supply that allows for a 5-minute interruption of power input. This allows for external battery packs to be hot-swapped during use.

name: HTC Vive XR Elite
description:
The HTC Vive XR Elite is a high-end lightweight virtual reality headset, making use of pancake optics to achieve a small form factor and improve comfort for the wearer. The headset makes use of many features from HTC's previous standalone devices; the Vive Flow & Vive Focus 3. This includes the use of pancake optics, inside-out tracked controllers, and an actively cooled chipset.

The HTC Vive XR Elite is intended to compete with Meta's Quest Pro, which was launched in October 2022, with a similar price and intended use case.

The HTC Vive XR Elite features many ergonomic characteristics, including a magnetically detachable facial interface, and the option to swap between two types of headstrap:

- A hot-swappable battery counterbalanced headstrap referred to as the "Battery Cradle"
- A pair of glasses-style arms that allow the headset to be easily taken on and off

The HTC Vive XR Elite makes use of HTC's Vive XR Controllers, which were originally released alongside the Vive Focus 3, and are compatible with both headsets.

The HTC Vive XR Elite was officially announced on January 5th during CES 2023.

name: Oculus Quest 2
description: Originally codenamed Del Mar, the Oculus Quest 2 is around 20% lighter and 15% smaller than its predecessor, the Oculus Quest, with a refresh rate of 120 Hz, improving on the 72 Hz of the original Quest. The Oculus Quest 2 can be connected to a PC via Oculus Link, which can be performed using the official Link cable or a third party USB-C cable. This allows the headset to be used to run content from SteamVR and the desktop Oculus store. Note that a high-bandwidth USB specification (USB 3.0 at a minimum) is required to achieve a high-quality and smooth picture. Alternatively, the Quest 2 can be used to play PC VR content wirelessly via use of Oculus' AirLink. In order to achieve a high quality wireless experience, a high-bandwidth router is required (IEEE 802.11ax / WiFi 6 is recommended). Alternatively, the third-party application, Virtual Desktop, can be used. Since Facebook's rebranding to Meta, the headset has been officially known as the Meta Quest 2, with all Oculus products and services being slowly rebranded under the Meta name.

name: Varjo Aero
description:
Varjo Aero is the first VR headset by Varjo intended for use by consumers as well as enterprise customers. Priced at $1999, it is one of the most expensive VR headsets released for the consumer market, as of 2021.

Previous Varjo devices required an annual software subscription to be made in order to be used, and were sold exclusively to businesses. The Aero, in an effort to become consumer-accessible, is being sold without this annual software subscription requirement.

The Varjo Aero is also the first consumer VR headset to use automatic hardware IPD adjustment. The device is equipped with eye-tracking cameras and a pair of adjustment motors to automatically detect and correct for the user's IPD.

Varjo Aero was initially priced at two thousand dollars, with its retail price being halved in September 2023 to just under a thousand dollars per unit.

name: Varjo XR-4
description:
Varjo XR-4 is Varjo's 4th generation virtual reality headset. As of its release, it offers the most advanced level of mixed reality passthrough and overall visual fidelity provided by the company so far.

Varjo XR-4 features dual Mini-LED displays with local dimming to provide high-contrast between dark and light areas of the wearer's view. It is also the first Varjo headset to ship with a pair of first-party inside-out tracked controllers, referred to as the Varjo Controllers.

name: Dream Glass Flow
description:
The Dream Glass Flow is a hybrid standalone / PC-powered pair of video glasses, intended to be used primarily for flat screen gaming and viewing video content.

The headset has an optional compute unit that allows for it to be used either as a standalone device or with a source PC, console, phone or tablet. Without the compute unit, the headset can be connected to a source device via HDMI or DisplayPort over USB-C, providing a virtual display for the wearer.

With the compute unit, referred to as the "Cloud Pack", content can be streamed over WiFi to the headset, and the Cloud Pack itself can also be used to directly connect to cloud gaming and video services, eliminating the need for an external video source entirely.

name: Meta Quest Pro
description:
The Meta Quest Pro is Meta's first mixed reality focused VR headset. Also referred to as "Seacliff" and "Project Cambria" during production, the headset is targeted primarily towards enterprise customers, with various notable improvements over the company's consumer focused headset, the Quest 2.

The Quest Pro is Meta's first headset to feature eye tracking and dynamic foveated rendering, which will be used to render graphics at a higher level of detail in comparison to the Quest 2..

The Quest Pro is also one of the first commercially available VR headsets to make use of pancake lenses, a multi-element lens design that significantly reduces the required distance between the display and the lenses, and subsequently the depth profile of the headset itself. This, combined with its counterbalanced headstrap, gives the device a much more favourable weight distribution when compared to the Quest 2.

The Quest Pro is also be the first Meta headset to feature full color passthrough, which facilitates use of the device for mixed reality, a feature demonstrated by Meta in promotional videos about the device.

The Meta Quest 3 is the first Meta headset to make use of the Snapdragon XR2 Gen 2 chipset, making it significantly more powerful than both the Quest 2 and the Quest Pro, while being priced significantly cheaper than the Quest Pro.

name: Rokid Air

The Rokid Air was announced via a promotional Indiegogo campaign. With an initial funding goal of $20,000, it was funded within the first day of the campaign. It features a manual focus adjustment system to accommodate myopic (near sighted) users.

The Rokid Air does not feature any positional tracking capability. It is intended to be used as a virtual display or video glasses only.

The Rokid Air Pro is intended primarily for use in training and exhibition purposes.

name: Rokid Max
description:
Rokid Max makes use of dual 1080p micro-OLED displays, providing a color gamut of sRGB 106% and a maximium percieved brightness of 600 nits, which can be adjusted using one of six levels.

Rokid Max is certified by TÜV Rhineland for low blue light, flicker-free, and eye comfort, ensuring that users can enjoy an AR experience without worrying about eye strain. The optics additionally offer a 90% reduction in forward light leakage, preventing the display from being easily viewed from in front of the device.

Rokid Max has physical buttons for brightnessand volume control. The glasses have adjustable nose pads and  built-in myopia correction from 0.00D to -6.00D, making them suitable for a wide range of potential wearers.

Rokid Max is compatible with devices that have USB-C DisplayPort and OTG, including smartphones running Android 10 and later.

name: Rokid Max Pro
description: Rokid Max Pro is an upgraded version of the Rokid Max, complete with monocular SLAM tracking, and hand-tracking capabilities.

name: NVIS nVisor SX60
description:
The SX60 was one of the most expensive VR headsets ever made, costing tens of thousands of dollars per-unit. The headset was intended for use in research, military, and other non-consumer applications.

The SX60 offers a very impressive resolution compared to other devices released in the same decade. The LCoS (Liquid Crystal on Silicon) display offered a very fast switching rate and a subpixel-less design that eliminated both ghosting and the screen door effect.

It also featured an InertiaCube IMU, used to provide a 3DoF head tracking experience.

name: Roscosmos XR-2
description:
The XR-2 was being developed by Roscosmos for use in training cosmonauts at the Russian Cosmonaut Training Center. The headset was intended to be used as a simulator manned spacecraft environments, including the Soyuz and Eagle spacecrafts. These simulation environments will also make use of non-VR technologies, including low-gravity simulations.

The headset was intended to compete with non-Russian VR devices, first on a commercial/corporate level, and later in the consumer space.

The Google Glass Enterprise Edition 2 is an AR headset designed for use by businesses. The headset consists of a monocular display and XR1-based integrated chipset, with multiple options of attachable frames including a lensless glasses frame, and safety frames designed by Smith Optics.

The headset is designed to be controlled via an integrated touchpad, and through voice commands.

The Google Glass Enterprise Edition 2 has an IP53 dust/water resistance rating.

name: Diver-X HalfDive
description:
The HalfDive is the first VR headset optimised for use in a bed. It features a varifocal lens system, wire-based force feedback, and a pair of fans designed to simulate wind on the user's face. Many of these features are viable due to the headset being statically installed in a location, rather than being supported by the user's head.

The headset is being initially offered to consumers via a Kickstarter campaign.

name: Everysight Raptor
cpu: Quad-core Cortex-A53 (4 x 1.2 GHz)
description:
The Everysight Raptor is an AR headset designed for use while cycling. It features a lightweight design, durable plastic construction and an IP55 water/dust resistance rating.

The headset can also be purchased alongside a controller, designed to be attached to the handlebars of a bike. The controller is IP67 dust & water resistance rated, and can be operated while wearing gloves.

name: Meta 2
description:
Meta (2016), the producer of the Meta 2, became defunct and was liquidated, with many of their assets and technologies being acquired by Campfire, and the design of the Meta 2 was later adapted for the Campfire Headset.

Note that Meta (2016) has no relation to Meta Platforms Inc, the company which was rebranded from Facebook and Oculus in 2021.

name: Engo Eyewear
description:
The Engo Eyewear features photochromic lenses that automatically adjust to a change in light conditions. Designed for use by cyclists and runners, the lenses also provide UV protection to the wearer's eyes for use in outdoor environments.

The Engo Eyewear also features a frame with flexible arms and nosepiece, that allows for the device to be shaped to the user's head.

The headset can be connected to bike computers, smartwatches, and smartphones via Bluetooth to display performance data such as heard rate, speed, and elevation.

The Engo Eyewear features a sensor allows the user to wave their hand in front of the lens to manipulate its user interface.

name: Engo 2
description:
Engo 2 features a standard size model weighing 36 grams, which is 7 grams lighter than the original Engo Eyewear, with the larger size model weighing the same amount as the original.

Engo 2 also features a redesigned frame and visor that makes the device look more like a pair of ordinary cycling glasses than the original Engo Eyewear.

Engo 2 features ActiveLook 2.0, with an increased feature set vs the original ActiveLook platform.

name: XYZ Atom
description: The XYZ Atom is an AR headset designed for use in the construction industry. It has a hardhat-integrated headstrap equipped with an integrated rear fan.
compliances: EN397, EN166, ANSI Z87.1, ANSI Z89.1
cpu: Octa-core i7

name: Cosmo Vision
description:
Cosmo Vision makes use of ActiveLook, a licenced hardware & software platform that provides an end-to-end system for displaying heads-up information to the wearer.

Cosmo Vision features a sensor allows the user to wave their hand in front of the lens to manipulate its user interface.

The Cosmo Vision also features an IP54 dust and water resistance rating, as well as a pair of photochromic blue mirrored lenses.

name: INMO Air
description:
The INMO Air is an Android-based standalone augmented reality headset that makes use of a ring-shaped controller, worn on the user's index finger. It was successfully crowdfunded in 2021 via an Indegogo campaign, which successfully raised over $250,000 from backers.

The INMO Ring, which is optionally sold alongside the headset, allows the user to control the device using gestures with their index finger. It also features an IP67 water/dust proof rating, and is capable of measuring heart rate, body temperature, and blood oxygen levels.

The INMO ring can be connected to the headset via Bluetooth, and will last for up to 2 days of standby time on a single charge. It was given out for free to those who had already backed the headset at the time of its announcement.
cpu: Quad-core Cortex-A53 (4 x 1.4 GHz)

name: INMO Air2
description: INMO Air2 was opened for pre-order on to the Chinese market on JD.com, and subsequently sold out its first batch of 1,000 units within 3 hours.

name: Simula One
description:
The Simula One is a standalone VR headset running SimulaOS, a desktop Linux based operating system and a VR headset focused window manager. The product is intended to be used primarily as a productivity tool, with the target audience including professionals and software engineers looking to work in a VR environment.

The headset is powered by a detachable Linux-based computing unit, and can natively run x86 programs. The headset also features  a tethered mode that can be used to connect the device to another PC in the absence of the included computing unit.

The Simula One's use of an intel-based x86 computing unit allows it to feature hardware normally not found in standalone headsets, including a 10-core 12-thread Intel CPU and a 1TB NVMe M.2 SSD.
cpu: 10-core 12-thread i7 (2 x 2 x 4.8 GHz, 8 x 3.6 GHz)

name: Somnium VR1
description:
The Somnium VR1 (previously known as the Somnium VR headset) is a modular VR headset, designed to be completely customisable by users on a hardware and software level.  Device owners are given unrestricted access to the controls and sensor inputs for the device in order to be able to make their own modifications. Many of the devices sensor modules can be removed via exposed screws and can be replaced or upgraded by users.

Somnium Space has also announced that 3D models of the headset will be made publicly available, with parts for the device being 3D-printable for customisation and repair.

The Somnium Space VR1 is being made in collaboration with VRgineers, and will feature lenses similar to those found in the VRgineers XTAL headsets.

(Pictured: Transparent Edition)
specData-refreshRate: 90 Hz mode available. ("144 Hz in the future")

name: Vuzix Blade Upgraded
description:
The Vuzix Blade Upgraded is a refined version of the original Vuzix Blade, equipped with upgraded audio capability, reinforced temples, and the capability of being used alongside peripherals including power banks and prescription lens inserts.

The Vuzix Blade Upgraded meets EN 166 & ANSI Z87.1 standards for eye protection, allowing it to be legally used as eye protection in industrial environments.

cpu: Octa-core
description:
The Vuzix Shield features stereo speakers with frame-integrated acoustic chambers, multiple noise-cancelling microphones, and two integrated cameras capable of recording at 4K 30fps.

The device can be controlled via a paired smartphone, as well as through voice commands, and a touch-sensitive arm that can be tapped to show or hide the display.

name: Vuzix M400
description: The Vuzix M400 is sold alongside two USB Type-C battery pack options. It is intended to be used with an external battery pack mounted on the frame and connected to the device. The internal battery has a 135 mAh capacity, and provides a short lifespan that can be used to allow hot-swapping of its external USB Type-C battery pack.
headstrap: Rail-mounted glasses-style frame / safety glasses / hardhat mount / headband mount /  Peltor headphone mount

name: Vuzix iWear VR920
description: The Vuzix iWear VR920 was primarily intended for use as a pair of video glasses, but also features an integrated 3 DoF head tracker, which was uncommon for video glasses at the time. The VR920 was marketed as being usable with PC video games such as Second Life and World of Warcraft, making use of Nvidia Stereoscopic Drivers to display a 3D view of the game to the user, complete with rotational head tracking.

name: Vuzix Blade 2
description:
The Vuzix Blade 2 is a slightly upgraded version of the Vuzix Blade Upgraded, featuring an updated Android 11 OS, an increased memory capacity, and improved WiFi capability.

Vuzix has also advertised the Blade 2 as featuring "increased security with integrated memory management", as well as "integration with common MDM solutions for easier device management".
cpu: Quad-core ARM CPU

name: Vuzix M400C
description: Vuzix M400C is a modified version of the Vuzix M400, designed to be connected to a source PC or smartphone via a USB Type-C connection. This allows the device to be used to view smartphone and desktop applications, and to send its camera output to the source device.
specData-deviceType: Can also be powered by a smartphone

name: Oppo Air Glass
description:
The Oppo Air Glass makes use of a monocle design similar to that of the original Google Glass. It is sold alongside a magnetic charging cradle, similar to that of a smartwatch, and a separate glasses-style frame that magnetically attaches to the device, allowing it to be worn by the user.

The Air Glass features a touch sensor on the device, as well as sensors allowing for control via voice commands or head movements. It can also be used alongside an Oppo Watch 2 to allow hand gesture control.

While the Oppo Air Glass is technically a standalone device, having its own SoC and operating system, it must be paired with an Oppo smartphone running the Smart Glass app in order to be used.
cpu: Quad-core Cortex A53 (4 x 1.7 GHz)
specData-deviceType: Must be paired with an Oppo smartphone

name: Shiftall MeganeX
description:
The Shiftall MeganeX is an ultra-lightweight Micro-OLED VR headset, designed to be used with a PC. The headset makes use of a Snapdragon XR1 to enable its inside-out tracking, but must be used with a wired video connection.

Shiftall is a subsidiary of Panasonic. A prototype of the MeganeX was demonstrated by Panasonic at CES 2021, with the official announcement of the MeganeX being made at CES 2022. The production model had some notable differences from the prototype, including its integrated tracking cameras.

The Shiftall MeganeX features an optional SteamVR tracking attachment, allowing the headset to be used with marker-based SteamVR 2.0 lighthouses.
cpu: Octa-core Kryo (2 x 2.52 GHz, 6 x 1.7 GHz)

name: Shiftall MeganeX Business Edition
description:
The Shiftall MeganeX Business Edition is an ultra-lightweight Micro-OLED VR headset, designed to be used with a PC. The headset makes use of a Snapdragon XR1 to enable its inside-out tracking, but must be used with a wired video connection.

The MeganeX Business Edition features built-in myopia support with adjustable diopter lenses, as well as a modified headstrap that replaces the head support with a nose pad to make the device easier to put on and take off.
cpu: Octa-core Kryo (2 x 2.52 GHz, 6 x 1.7 GHz)

name: Shiftall MeganeX Superlight 8K
description:
Shiftall MeganeX Superlight 8K is a lightweight Micro-OLED & pancake optics-based headset that makes use of a variety of techniques including its optical stack, headstrap design, and lack of standalone capability to maximize comfort and lightness.

Weighing around 185 grams, the device is one of the lightest VR headsets available to consumers, and its forehead pad headstrap design allows the visor to be flipped up while being worn, making the device ideal for use by VR developers as well as consumers.
headstrap: Fabric strap with padded halo-style forehead pad

name: RealWear HMT-1
headstrap: Headband / hat clips / bump cap / tri-band strap
cpu: Octa-core Cortex-A53 (8 x 2 GHz)

name: RealWear HMT-1Z1
description:
The HMT-1Z1 is the first wearable display to meet Class 1 Division 1 and ATEX & IECEx Zone 1 certifications. This allows the device to be used in potentially explosive atmospheres without presenting a risk of ignition.

The HMT-1Z1 is intended for use primarily in the oil and gas industry, as well as similar environments where flammable and explosive materials are routinely handled.
headstrap: Overhead strap & rear pad / hard hat clips
cpu: Octa-core Cortex-A53 (8 x 2 GHz)

name: RealWear Navigator 500
description:
The RealWear Navigator 500 features a modular design, with a hot-swappable battery that allows the device to be used continuously over multiple battery charges.

The headset also features a camera with a telephoto mode, that offers up to 4x zoom at 1080p resolution, and up to 6x zoom at 720p.

The RealWear Navigator 500 has an IP66 dust and water resistance rating.
cpu: Octa-core Kryo 260 (4 x 2 GHz, 4  x 1.8 GHz)

name: RealWear Navigator 520
description:
The RealWear Navigator 520 features an improved display vs the Navigator 500, offering 20% more screen space and an improves 720p resolution.

The RealWear Navigator 520 also offers a larger eye relief range, allowing the wearer to position the display further from their eye if desired.
cpu: Octa-core Kryo 260 (4 x 2 GHz, 4 x 1.8 GHz)

name: RealWear Navigator Z1
description: The RealWear Navigator Z1 features an integrated tensor chip to allow for AI workloads to be processed on board the device.
compliances: ATEX Zone 1, CSA C1/D1, IP66, MIL-STD-810H

name: Epson Moverio BT-40
description:
The Epson Moverio is part of Epson's fourth generation of wearable AR devices. It features a wider field of view than previous products by the company, and has an updated headset design with improved weight distribution and comfort.

The Moverio BT-40 also features dual 1080p displays with a 500,000:1 contrast ratio. A shade attachment can also be placed on top of the optics in order to reduce the amount of light passing through the display.

name: VictorMaxx CyberMaxx
description:
The VictorMaxx CyberMaxx features a belt-clipped power supply unit intended to be worn by the user.

1994 financial statements from VictorMaxx reported a revenue of $606,143, indicating that 867 units were sold within the first two months of its release.

name: Tilt Five
description:
The Tilt Five uses features integrated LCoS projectors that are reflected back into the user's eyes via a retroreflective game board. This allows the headset to have a very wide field of view, but can only display images when the user is looking at the retroreflective board surface.

Tilt Five is intended for use as a tabletop gaming device, allowing one or more players to view stereoscopic 3D content on the game board. The company provides a Unity SDK to allow developers to incorporate support for the device into their games, with a sizeable range of video games on Steam supporting the device.
specData-deviceType: Android support planned

name: eMagin Z800 3DVisor
description: The eMagin Z800 3DVisor was intended to be used with Nvidia's Stereoscopic 3D Drivers.

name: Carl Zeiss Cinemizer OLED
description:
The Cinemizer OLED was designed primarily for use as video glasses without tracking capability, but can be purchased alongside an optional unit that provided rotational head tracking (3 degrees of freedom). Competing alongside other products of the time such as Sony's HMZ-T1 3D glasses, the optional rotational tracking capability of the headset gave the device an edge over competitors.

The Cinemizer OLED, while used as video glasses, could be connected older iPhone models such as the iPhone 4 and iPhone 5 with an optional adapter accessory. This allowed the device to be used to view video content from the user's phone.

Despite being intended solely for use as a PC-powered device, the Cinemizer OLED featured an integrated battery that had to be recharged, rather than drawing power from the display source device. This battery would last up to 6 hours depending on the video source, but if used through HDMI would only last for around 2.5 hours.
specData-deviceType: Can also be powered by a smartphone

name: VPL EyePhone
description: The VPL EyePhone is generally considered to be the first commercially released VR headset, available for purchase by businesses and the general public. The full EyePhone setup, consisting of the headset, a DataGlove controller, as well as a PC setup and video control unit, could be purchased as a complete package for $250,000.
controllerFingerTracking: Full thumb and finger tracking
controllerInputMethods: Optical fiber bend sensors (1 per finger)
specData-price: Includes PC system for powering the device

name: Virtuality Visette 1
description:
The Virtuality Visette 1 was sold as part of two larger VR systems, the 1000CS (Cyber Space) and 1000SD (Sit Down). The 1000CS was a standing VR system composed of the Visette 1, pod designed for the user to stand in, and a "space joystick". The 1000SD was a similar system, using a pod designed for the user to sit inside rather than a standing pod.

Both the 1000CS and 1000SD systems were powered by an Amiga 3000. Approximately 350 Virtuality 1000CS units were created, retailing for $60,000 and sold for use in arcades and shopping malls.

The Visette 1, combined with the Amiga 3000, could render up to 30,000 polygons at at 20 frames per second.
specData-deviceType: Powered by an Amiga 3000

name: Virtuality Visette 2
description: The Virtuality Visette 2 was sold as part of two larger VR systems, the 2000CS (Cyber Space) and 2000SD (Sit Down). The 2000CS was a standing VR system while the 2000SD was a seated VR system. These systems are based off of the previous generation Virtuality 1000CS and 1000SD units, which made use of the original Virtuality Visette 1 headset.
specData-deviceType: Powered by an accompanying IBM PC

name: Snap Spectacles (2021)
description:
The Snap Spectacles (2021), also known as Snap Spectacles 4 or Next Generation Spectacles, is Snap Inc's 4th generation smart glasses product. The Snap Spectacles 4th gen are the company's first pair of smart glasses to incorporate true AR functionality, featuring 6 DoF tracking and native passthrough AR waveguide displays.

The Snap Spectacles (2021) use the company's proprietary Snap Spatial Engine, which provides a "15 millisecond motion to photon latency" during use.

The 4th gen Snap Spectacles are unavailable for purchase, but can be obtained by applying as an AR creator via the Spectacles website.

The 4th gen Snap Spectacles are not water resistant in any way.
cpu: Octa-core Kryo (2 x 2.52 GHz, 6 x 1.7 GHz)
specData-batteryLife: Comes with charging case holding 4 charges

name: AjnaLens AjnaXR
description:
AjnaXR is Ajnalens' first mixed reality headset release, featuring a lightweight and ergonomic design making use of pancake optics and a battery-counterbalanced headstrap.

AjnaXR does not require a social sign in to be used.

AjnaXR was announced during CES 2023.

AjnaXR is Ajnalens' first mixed reality headset release, featuring a lightweight and ergonomic design making use of pancake optics and a battery-counterbalanced headstrap.

name: Campfire Headset
description:
The Campfire Headset is intended to be used for collaboration on product design and engineering projects. The headset is sold alongside the Campfire Console, a large X-shaped tracking marker used to anchor a CAD model being worked on to a specific location in the physical world.

Additionally, the Campfire Headset makes use of a novel controller, the Campfire Pack, that attaches to the user's phone to allow it to be used as a pointer device for manipulating 3D objects being worked on.

The Campfire Headset is primarily intended for use as an AR device, but a magnetically attachable cover allows for the headset to be used in a virtual reality mode.

The Campfire headset is initially available under an early access program, with a commercial release intended for 2022.
specData-controllers: Must be attached to a smartphone

name: Fujitsu FMVHDS1
description:
The Fujitsu FMVHDS1 (also known more simply as "Fujitsu Windows Mixed Reality Headset") is a part of the first generation of Windows Mixed Reality headsets, and makes use of the same controller design as other first gen WMR headsets.

The Fujitsu FMVHDS1 was released to consumers in Japan in early 2018.

name: Viture One
description:
The Viture One can be used as a virtual screen with any USB Type-C device with video output and power delivery. Additionally, there are two optional extra devices that are sold alongside the glasses:

- A neckband that enables the Viture One to be used with Bluetooth devices as well as wireless casting (e.g. Miracast)
- A "Mobile Dock" that allows the glasses to be used with any HDMI or DisplayPort over USB-C video connection

It is important to note that the Viture One is a pair of video glasses, and does not feature rotational or positional tracking of any kind.

Viture One was funded via a successful Kickstarter campaign on April 20th, 2022.

The Viture Pro XR Glasses feature dual 1080p 120 Hz displays, offering 4000 nits of brightness, an improvement over the 1800 nits offered by the Viture One. They include myopia adjustments and an electrochromic film that blocks up to 99.5% of external light.

Viture Pro also features an aluminium construction with titanium hinges to ensure the durability of the product.

The TCL NXTWEAR S was originally announced as the TCL NXTWEAR Air during CES 2022, and was later rebranded. It will be launched via a Kickstarter campaign in late 2022.

The TCL NXTWEAR S features a removable glasses insert that can be fitted with prescription lenses for glasses wearers. These lenses must be acquired from a third party.

The TCL NXTWEAR S also features interchangeable front lenses to modify the visual appearance of the device.

The TCL NXTWEAR V offers a feature that allows the wearer to share their screen with a flat-screen device on the same WiFi network with a single button press, allowing the wearer to easily work with those nearby who may not be wearing a headset themselves.

The TCL NXTWEAR V offers a centralised control software that allows for multiple headsets to be controlled from a conventional computer, allowing for ease of use in scenarios such as education or training, where large groups of people are all individually using headsets to view the same piece of content.

TCL RayNeo X2 is the marketed as "the world's first binocular full-color micro-LED optical waveguide AR glasses". The device features two waveguide displays allowing for binocular AR content to be displayed in color to the wearer.

The TCL RayNeo X2 makes use of an integrated Snapdragon XR2 chipset to provide advanced functionality, including realtime mapping of locations and translation of text and spoken language.

TCL RayNeo X2 was announced during CES 2023.

name: Skyworth W1
description:
The Skyworth W1(also known as the Skyworth S6) is a lightweight 3 DoF tracked VR headset intended for use primarily for watching immersive video content. The headset features a lightweight design, as well as diopter and IPD adjustment to provide a comfortable usage experience for the wearer.

It should be noted that the majority of Skyworth headsets are sold with a larger nosepiece in western markets, and a smaller nosepiece in eastern markets. As such, Skyworth devices imported directly from China may not fit wearers from western countries appropriately.

The headset features a lightweight design, as well as diopter and IPD adjustment to provide a comfortable usage experience for the wearer.

It should be noted that the majority of Skyworth headsets are sold with a larger nosepiece in western markets, and a smaller nosepiece in eastern markets. As such, Skyworth devices imported directly from China may not fit wearers from western countries appropriately.

name: Brilliant Labs Frame
description:
Frame is a pair of monocular smartglasses with an open-source design, and is Brilliant Labs' second AR device release, after Monocle, which was launched in 2023.

Frame is marketed as a pair of "multimodal AI glasses", with connections to various AI services including those of OpenAI, Whisper, and Perplexity, providing additional functionality for the wearer.

Frame can pair with the wearer's smartphone using the Brilliant's Noa app, allowing it to connect with various AI chat services to enhance the wearer's experience.

Frame is available in three colors: Black, gray, and transparent.

Frame is sold alongside Mister Power a charging adapter / battery pack that can be used to recharge the glasses when they run out of power, and can itself be recharged via a USB-C port.

name: DigiLens Argo
description:
DigiLens Argo is an XR2-based AR product targeted primarily towards the enterprise and industrial markets. It is intended to be controlled primarily through voice commands.

Argo's optics are designed to be highly transparent, with a light transmittance of approx. 85% vs HoloLens 2's approx. 70% transmittance.

DigiLens is known primarily for producing waveguides for use in other augmented reality devices, with Argo being the company's first commercial augmented reality headset to be developed first-party.
cpu: Octa-core Kryo 585 (1 x 2.84 GHz, 3 x 2.42 GHz, 4 x 1.8 GHz)

name: Bigscreen Beyond
description:
Bigscreen beyond is a lightweight SteamVR-tracked headset that makes use of pancake optics to achieve a very small form factor and overall weight.

Bigscreen beyond features a custom-made facial interface that is designed based on a 3D scan of the purchaser's face, allowing the headset to be fitted more accurately, reducing light bleed and increasing comfort while in use.

Additionally, Bigscreen beyond features a fixed IPD setting that is also custom-made to fit the user's IPD based on a 3D scan of their face at the time of purchase.
specData-ipdRange: Fixed IPD, custom made based on purchaser's face scan

name: Bigscreen Beyond 2
description: Bigscreen Beyond 2 is Bigscreen's second ultra-lightweight PC-powered VR headset release. It features an extremely small form factor and a roughly 20% weight reduction from the original Bigscreen Beyond.

name: Bigscreen Beyond 2e
description:
Bigscreen Beyond 2e is a modified version of Bigscreen's Beyond 2 headset, with the addition of an eye tracking system integrated into the headset.

The eye tracking system is advertised as "the world's smallest eye tracking sensor suite with an image sensor the size of a grain of sand". In practical terms this means that the inclusion of eye tracking only adds a single gram to the total weight of the headset, bringing it up to 108 g excluding headstrap, vs 107g for the original Beyond 2.

name: P&C Solution METALENSE
cpu: Octa-core Kryo 585 (1 x 2.84 GHz, 3 x 2.42 GHz, 4 x 1.8 GHz)

name: Virtual Research Flight Helmet
description:
The Virtual Research Flight Helmet was produced for use in avionics simulations. It was not available to the general public, being targeted towards the business sector, priced at $6000 for a single unit.

It features early LCD displays, which offered an improved form factor when compared to CRTs (the dominant display technology at the time) at the cost of a lower resolution.
headstrap: Integrated helmet with internal adjustable headstrap

name: Virtual Research VR4
description: Virtual Research VR4 makes use of the same headband system as Virtual Research's previous product, the EYEGEN 3

name: Thunderbird Air Plus
description: Thunderbird is an XR technology startup owned by the technology manufacturer, TCL. They produce augmented reality and virtual reality products for the Chinese and western markets, with their headsets typically being rebranded under the NXTWEAR name for western releases.
specData-deviceType: Requires optional compute unit

name: Spacetop
description:
Spacetop is an "Augmented Reality Laptop" product, consisting of a laptop chassis with a keyboard and trackpad, and a hardwired pair of Nreal Light AR glasses. The device is marketed as the "World's first AR laptop".

Spacetop features a Qualcomm SoC and a custom operating system designed specifically for the product. It is being sold initially in a first batch of 1000 units towards "web-forward" customers, and is designed primarily for browser-based workflows.

The product is marketed as a 13-inch laptop with a virtual "100-inch screen".

Spacetop was released as an early access product available in limited supply to early backers.
cpu: Octa-core Kryo 585 (1 x 3.1 GHz, 3 x 2.42 GHz, 4 x 2.1 GHz)

name: Spacetop G1
description:
Spacetop G1 is Sightful's second AR device, and the second AR product with a laptop and glasses style form factor.

Spacetop G1 consists of a pair of Xreal Air 2 AR glasses, hardwired into a laptop chassis. The device is complete with a Qualcomm chipset and an integrated custom OS, designed to compete against traditional laptops while providing privacy and extra screen real estate to the user.
cpu: Octa-core Kryo (1 x 3.2 GHz, 4 x 2.8 GHz, 3 x 2.0 GHz)

name: Apple Vision Pro
description:
Apple Vision Pro is Apple's first XR device, intended to be used primarily for mixed reality content. It features a front display that shows the wearer's eyes, allowing the wearer to make eye contract with others outside of the headset.

Apple Vision Pro uses iris scanning to authenticate users while wearing the headset, allowing for the wearer to security make payments and access secure resources.

Apple Vision Pro required the filing of over 5000 patents for technologies used in the device.

Apple Vision Pro was announced during Apple's Keynote speech at WWDC 2023.
cpu: Octa-core Avalanche / Blizzard (4 x 3.5 GHz, 4 x 2.4 GHz)

name: Nubia Neovision Glass

name: Immersed Visor
description:
Immersed Visor is a lightweight headset intended to be used with Immersed, a productivity program that uses a VR headset to provide virtual monitors for a PC environment. It is advertised as being "25% lighter than a smartphone", while still offering wireless PCVR capability. This is achieved through the use of an external battery pack / compute unit with a WiFi module to allow the wearer to stream VR content wirelessly from their PC.

Note that the battery pack is also required to use the headset as a wired PCVR device, with the wearer having to connect the battery pack to a host PC via a USB Type-C cable.

Immersed Visor features a front plate that can be removed to expose the passthrough cameras if desired.

Immersed also offers a "Founder's Edition" for Visor,  which is being sold in a limited run of 25,000 units, and includes a limited custom faceplate and a lifetime subscription to Immersed's premium service tier.

name: Xreal Air 2
description: Xreal Air 2 (sometimes stylised as Xreal Air2) features various improvements over the original Xreal Air. This includes a lighter and thinner frame, as well as flexible arms to improve comfort while worn.

name: Xreal Air 2 Pro
description:
Xreal Air 2 Pro (sometimes stylised as Xreal Air2 Pro) features various improvements over the original Xreal Air. This includes a lighter and thinner frame, as well as flexible arms to improve comfort while worn.

Additionally, Xreal Air 2 Pro features electrochromic lenses that can be dimmed to reduce the amount of environmental light visible to the wearer if desired. This feature is not found on the base Air 2 model and can is only available on Xreal Air 2 Pro.

name: Xreal Air 2 Ultra
description:
Xreal Air 2 Ultra is an improved version of the original Xreal 2, featuring advanced features including integrated head and hand tracking (via two integrated cameras), and a durable titanium frame.

Xreal AIr 2 features tracking capabilities that allow hand gesture recorgnition, and can produce a depth mesh of the wearer's environment with semantic labelling of objects in the space.

Xreal Air 2 is the company's second pair of AR glasses to feature 6 DoF tracking, the first of which being the Nreal Light, released in 2020.

Xreal Air 2 is compatible with Mac and Windwos devices, Samsung Android phones, and iPhones.
compliances: TUV flicker-free, low blue light, eye comfort, color accuracy

name: Xreal One
description:
Xreal One features several features to improve user experience, including 3 DoF tracking, facilitated through the inclusion of a custom in-house developed chipset. This allows the wearer to place a virtual screen in their environment, or have the screen gently follow their gaze rather than being locked to the center of the display.

Xreal One features integrated settings to allow the wearer to adjust the placement and distance of their virtual screen.

Xreal One features integrated speakers designed by Bose.

name: Xreal One Pro
description:
Xreal One Pro features an improved optical design vs Xreal One, with a field of view seven degrees larger than the original Xreal One. Additionally, Xreal One Pro features brighter displays, capable of producing an image with a brightness of 700 nits after passing through the optical stack.

name: XEO BIG
description:
XEO BIG is a lightweight PC-powered headset making use of a micro-OLED pancake & lens stack to minimize footprint and weight.

XEO BIG differs from many other lightweight PC-powered VR headsets such as Bigscreen Beyond, in that it features integrated inside-out tracking, allowing it to be used without SteamVR lighthouses.
